channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Cutting-edge bioinformatics company in Australia looking for programmer with excellent Modern Perl skills, ideally with Dancer, at least some familiarity with JavaScript on the front-end, and an openness to learning new things – there’s a learning curve regarding the domain knowledge, but they’ll be happy to teach you.

item.title: All Aboard to Your Next Adventure! Perl Role in Malta
item.description: Perl programmers rejoice — our client has an office in Malta, and they’re looking for you. As a financial company seeing incredible growth over the last two decades, business is booming and they’re looking to expand their team. If you’ve got an interest in dollars and cents and share their belief that online trading should be available to all, we’ve got the role for you.

item.title: Smart Shopper = Smart Saver. Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Very well-known Austrian e-commerce brand willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl. Benefits include free lunch, coworkers with exceptional table football skills, and a relaxed policy to time management.

item.title: A New Adventure is only a Click Away. Perl Developer role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Mad Men (and women) of London. Perl in London
item.description: The leader in premium native advertising for technology, financial services, and corporate and lifestyle sectors, our client is the power behind the advertising throne for over 200 websites, including Forbes, Wall Street Journal, CNN Business, and The Washington Post. This dynamic team is looking for a senior Perl programmer.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 8-10 June 2021.

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Git Hooks(Client-side)
item.description: Thursday, May 6, 2021

item.description: Wednesday, May 12, 2021

item.description: Thursday, April 29, 2021

item.description: Wednesday, April 28, 2021

item.title: Live Pair programming events
item.description: The list of past events with video recordings and the schedule

item.title: Getting started with Git and GitHub
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Mejorar la libreria de GitHub::Actions en Perl con Juan J. Merelo
item.description: The first time I pair-programmed in (broken) Spanish. Find further events here.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109: Chowla Squares
item.description: Roger shared two different approaches to solve the Four Squares Puzzle task. Interesting, you must check out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109: Choowa Numbers and Sums
item.description: Luca came up with compact solutions in Raku. Well done. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109
item.description: Thanks for reminding us about the Permutator from the Higher Order Perl book.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109: Chowla Numbers and Four Square Puzzle
item.description: Laurent seems to read my mind, smart brain. He guessed it correctly output is not part of the requirements. Thank You.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 109
item.description: I loved how Jaldhar found the similarity between Four Squares Puzzle and Olympic Rings task. Very smart.

item.title: PWC109 - Four Squares Puzzle
item.description: Flavio never just solve the task but also gave us more than just solution. You don't want to miss out.

item.title: PWC109 - Chowla Numbers
item.description: Very nicely organised one-line subroutines. Looks elegant and clean. Great work.

item.title: Iterations and Permutations: Perl Weekly Challenge 109
item.description: I loved the use of grep to solve the Chowla Numbers task. Great work.

item.title: Dividing Sums into Four Squares
item.description: I liked how the beautifully the Raku solution is presented. I wish Perl can also be coded like it.

item.title: CY's Take on PWC#109
item.description: Cheok-Yin took the challenge to another level, you have to checkout yourself. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109 solution
item.description: I loved the comparison between Perl and Python. You will definitely enjoy the discussion.

item.title: Chowla Squared with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne once again not only shares the solution but also shows the internals as well. Keep it up.

item.title: Chowla Numbers and Numbers in Boxes: The Weekly Challenge 109
item.description: I must thank Adam for keeping Prolog in the loop and giving us the glimpse of it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109: Four Squares Puzzle
item.description: Again, there are plenty of different ways to deal with task discussed in the blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109: Chowla Numbers
item.description: Technical aspects of the task is discussed in details, Thanks Abigail.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 109
item.description: Don't forget to check out the 'Specific Comments' section. Always packed with cool magics.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 109
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Chowla Numbers" and "Four Squares Puzzle" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 110
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Valid Phone Numbers" and "Transpose File". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: March report of the Raku Development Grant of Jonathan Worthington
Course Management Application in Mojolicious - part 3
item.description: The 3rd part of the live coding series with Mark Gardner and Gabor Szabo. We get lots of good advice both during the live event and after. If you'd like to join us next time see the schedule.

item.title: All partitions of a set into same-sized subsets
An improved GUI for cme and Config::Model
All partitions of a set - rearranging addends
Use Immutable Objects
item.description: The little I understand the state of programming, I think there is a trend going towards more immutable objects. In Perl there are not many such objects, even constants are just functions. So it will be interesting to see how this works out. Will having immutables reduce the bugs in our code as promised by many or will that juts increase the complexity?

item.title: All partitions of a set - preliminary considerations
Localizing dates in a Perl web application
item.description: It must be a lot of fun looking at text, even just dates in various languages and various character sets. And Mark did not even mentioned that if he wanted to use the Hebrew calendar then instead of Arabic numbers (0-9) that is used throuought the world (well except in Arabic :-), we use the Hebrew letters as numbers as well.

item.title: All positive integer sums, as iterator
mySociety is looking for a Perl Developer - could it be you?
item.description: Pioneering not-for-profit group mySociety is hiring a Perl Developer to join their growing team and help to develop public sector services that help active citizens support flourishing communities; done simply, responsibly and cost effectively. Is it you they're looking for? Apply by 7th May 2021.

item.title: #509 - Community Affairs
item.description:
Hi there!

The Perl Foundation has posted two reports from the CAT, the Community Affairs Team. In one of them it was discussing actions taken agains two individuals. They don't name the two people so I can only guess who they are. The links were posted to the Perl Subredit raising all kinds of claims agains it claiming that the TPF post is a personal attack on someone. Subsequently the post was removed from the Perl (Sub)Reddit.

It was unclear to me if the complaints against the post were made by those who were (not) mentioned in the CAT report, their devoted friends, or just by people who think that being nasty on an ongoing basis to others is an acceptable behaviour, but talking about it and condeming it is not.

I had a tradition of posting the link of the Perl Weekly to Reddit every time it was publish. I am afraid this time I won't be able to do it as this post will be considered a personal attack on some unnamed person who seems to be holy.

As for me, for a long time I have not felt part of some 'Perl community'. I try to serve the people who use Perl, I work with people for whom Perl is their main source of income. I like many of the people who are in and around what some call the 'Perl community', but due to the behaviour of some individuals I also keep my distance. And frankly, I am sad.

Well, that's it for now

I hope you'll enjoy your week!
